The school has a formal cooperation agreement with the University of Oslo with a special focus on biology and geosciences and a cooperation agreement with Oslo University hospital which includes five hospitals in Oslo. The school’s vision is: The future begins with us. Our values are to be responsible, competent and outward. The school wishes inquisitive students who would like to use their resources and complete their education. The pedagogical work has focus on assessment for learning and the use of varied learning arenas within and outside the school. Learning outside the school expands through internationalization to “the classroom beyond the borders of our country”. Hersleb has in its strategic plan goals about increased activity within internationalization. The goal for the project is both to recruit students for health- and youth studies, reputation management and to give the students an edge in the competition for jobs. The project will create academic motivation and increase the width in educational training. The students must compete to participate after decided criteria, and this will have a positive effect regarding less absence and reduce the risk of quitting school. They will develop independency and maturity through taking choices and mastering new situations. They will experience respect for other countries’ vocational training and see forces about their own education. The meeting between participants in the project creates new networks where leaders, teachers and students get new insight and professional input. Friendship between students across the country borders and meeting with other cultures involves increasing tolerance and equality. It prevents racism and prejudice. Many of the school’s students are minority speakers, and the students have a lot of experience from different languages and cultures, and this is a resource in the international cooperation. Internationalization gives the health- and youth studies more attention and status. Hersleb high school has good experiences with exchange within health- and youth studies including Finland, Spain (Erasmus+) and Germany (Do it!). The academic dividend for the participants has been great both professionally and socially, something the rest of the organization benefits from. Further, internationalization has created new friendships and good cohesion between colleagues which still is safeguarded. The school’s management represented by the headmaster has the main responsibility for the project application, and the department manager for the health- and youth studies is the contact. The department manager has had the main responsibility for internationalization through several years and has participated at many courses directed by SIU. In addition, the operations of the projects are organized by experienced coordinators. The school has built a network which gives the projects a quality assurance and makes them predictable. The projects have developed cooperation across subjects and stages, and new and experienced teachers participate.The project gives work practice and school practice for students within health- and youth studies in all stages. To each project country it will be applied for economic support for 2–6 participants and 1–2 teachers. The teachers will follow up academically and socially. Hersleb high school has an intention agreement with the following partners:City College Brighton & Hove is an educational institution within language and professional subjects which offers a holistic plan with accommodation, language courses and deployment in kindergartens and senior centers. This is a new project partner who contributes to develop the school’s work for internationalization.Fundation Noruega Costa Blanca (FNCB) has long experience with international projects. The school is an educational office submitted to the county of Rogaland and regularly receives apprentices from the health- and youth studies. The school cooperates with hospitals, doctor’s offices and dental offices where the students can be deployed at workplaces. YA Vocational College of Ostrobothnia is a big professional arena with accommodation. Norwegian students will participate in the school’s instruction and have practice in health sciences.Hersleb high school will be active to use the experiences from the project in marketing of the school, on the home page and in social media. The school will spread knowledge to the school’s cooperative partners and the Oslo schools in general in relevant forums. The school’s students will have responsibility in this work regarding recruitment from secondary schools and parent groups.The school’s future plans are to develop international projects within geosciences and biology. The goal is to expand the network for teachers, students, leaders and companies.

The consortium of Vocational Education and Training (VET) schools meets the growing needs of VET mobility in the “Académie de Lille” (regional education authority).
In this « Académie », lots of secondary school pupils are sent to vocational schools and most of these vocational students won't get any higher education degrees.

The consortium relies on academic and school partnership.
This project has several general aims: to improve the students’ skills and key knowledge linked with the labour market, to make European lifelong vocational education and training programme better known, to improve the linguistic diversity in the EU. The specific aims of the consortium are: to help and assist schools, to be a major European agent for young people, to reinforce multidisciplinary approach, to promote innovative educational methods, to be key partners for companies, to create a real partnership between both educational and professional worlds, to increase European activities in Les Hauts de France region.

The consortium is composed of four upper secondary schools:

Lycée professionel Aimé Césaire, the consortium head office and member.
The school is situated in Lille Metropole (MEL) and hosts 515 students. It offers industrial vocational training (such as metalwork, ironwork, electricity and home automation. It also offers a service sector training (multi-specialised sales representative level V, trade and sale, customer care, hospitality and services, management and administration level IV).
45 students will benefit from a VET learning mobility between 2017 and 2019.

Lycée Hôtelier International de Lille (LHIL) offers training (from level III to V) in catering, food and floristry, a technology baccalaureate (level IV) in hospitality and higher education training for apprentices with a BTS (Advanced vocational certificate or BTEC HND, level III) in hospitality too.
There are 465 students attending the lycée and 212 apprentices attending the UFA (apprentice training centre). Lycée hôtelier Michel Servet has become the LHIL (European and International Hotel and Catering school).
 14 students and 4 staff members will benefit from a VET learning mobility between 2017 and 2019.

Lycée Dinah Derycke in Villeneuve d'Ascq offers industrial training (industrial design, electricity, electronics and energy level IV) and service sector training (management and administration, trade and sale, hospitality and services + administration level IV). 
52 students will benefit from a VET learning mobility between 2017 and 2019.

Lycée du Hainaut in Valenciennes offers several higher education trainings with « classes préparatoires » (intensive two-year post baccalaureate courses) and a BTS (Advanced vocational certificate or BTEC HND), initial vocational education trainings such as « 3ème Prepapro » (lower secondary vocational class) and level V (automotive sector, Logistics & Warehousing), level IV (machining, bodywork, electronics, sheet metal work, management and administration). It is also a “Lycée général et technologique” (a senior and technological high school) and an apprenticeship centre. 24 students and 2 staff members will benefit from a VET learning mobility between 2017 and 2019.

The mobility project team (composed of the four members of the consortium PIMEN5_A. CESAIRE) meet three times a year and will deal with points related to the project management. Each school / the schools will work in close cooperation with the DAREIC (the academic delegation dedicated to the European, international relations and cooperation). The members of the consortium regularly correspond by e-mail and phone. A shared e-mail address has been created (ce.pimen@ac-lille.fr) so that the schools could receive a quick answer either from the applicant or from the « Rectorat » (Local Education Authority)

The advantages for the students are:
- An easier access to higher education or employability thanks to the Europass diploma,
- Improved foreign language skills thanks to the commitment of foreign host companies,
- A better professional mobility. 
- Encouragement for the students to take and pass the « mention Euro » (added to their vocational baccalaureate diploma).

This investment will also contribute to the standing of the schools, to the ambition of the MEL (Lille Metropole), which is  a European dimension conurbation, and to the awareness of future applicants.

The organization of an exchange day between learners and partners will enable us to draw lessons from the VET learning mobility.

Hersleb Upper Secondary School is located downtown in Oslo. We have approx. 700 students who study either general studies or the vocational program Healthcare, Childhood and Youth Development. The main values for Hersleb, as reflected in the school’s strategic development plan, is respect, responsibility and compassion. These values are visible in all that is done at Hersleb. Our pedagogical work focuses on assessment for learning and the use of varied learning arenas within and outside the school. Hence, cooperation with partners on a local and international level is an important element in our work. Among the partner organizations  we have formal cooperation agreements with are the University of Oslo, where we cooperate within the fields biology and geoscience, and Oslo University Hospital, where our students have in-service training at one of their five hospitals. The school's outreach policy also expands through international projects to "The Classroom Beyond Borders."

International projects represent a key element in Hersleb's strategic development plan. This project's aim is to promote intercultural competence and EU citizenship, to recruit students to Health and Youth Studies, strengthen integration and equality, and develop language and social science skills. The project generates academic motivation and expands the school's teaching methodology, thus strengthening our reputation. Students wishing to participate in projects must compete on set criteria, a competition that leads to higher school attendance and a reduced risk of early school leaving. Taking responsibility and mastering new situations helps make our students more independent and mature. Students gain respect for other countries' vocational training while at the same time seeing the strength of their own educational system. Meeting project partners generates new networks where leaders, teachers and students gain new insight and input. Making friends abroad and experiencing new cultures creates greater tolerance and acceptance of diversity, which again counters prejudice and racism. Many of our students have a minority background and are well-versed in languages and culture, which is a resource in international cooperation. Nonetheless, they lack prior experience with travelling abroad, so international projects foster personal growth. The project also gives our students an edge in the labour marked.

Hersleb’s Department of Healthcare and Youth Studies have positive experiences with foreign exchanges. Since the school opened in 2014, several tens have been sent to partners in Finland, Spain, England and Germany. The academic dividend for the participants has been substantial, both socially and professionally, something the rest of the school benefits from. Also, internationalization has created new friendships and a network of professional collaboration that we carefully maintain. 

The school's administration represented by the principal has the main responsibility for the project application, and head of the Department of Healthcare and Youth Studies is the contact person.  Additionally, project coordinators will help organize the project. The school has for several years worked to established an international network which ensures that all our projects hold a high standard and are predictable. These projects have led to teachers cooperating across subjects and stages.

The specific projects which we are applying for financing of will provide work placement and schooling for students who are in their 2nd or final year. We are applying for financial support for 8-12 participants and 1-2 teachers for each mobility. The project partners  we wish to involve in this project are:
1) Fundation Noruega Costa Blanca. The school is an educational office submitted to the county of Rogaland, that has extensive international experience and regularly receives apprentices from Health and Youth Studies. The school cooperates with local hospitals, doctor's offices and dental clinics where students can have in-service training. 
2) Greater Brighton Metropolitan College. This is a government college whose main focus is vocational study, and they will offer a holistic plan for our students which includes language courses, in-service training at healthcare institutions and accommodation with host families. 
3) Berufsbildende Schule 3 is a new partner. There will be a mutual exchange of students between Norway and Germany, where involved students will receive schooling and in-service training in the receiving country. 

Hersleb actively uses our international projects when marketing our school – on our webpages and in social media. We share the results of our projects with partners within and outside the school. Students take part in this work by speaking to new students and parents. Together we try to send the message that international projects make us a better school where students can come and complete their education with good marks.

Practical Hairdressing course enabling students from City College Brighton and Hove to take part in a mobility to Kuben School Norway, building on an existing partnership with the school which bought students from Kuben to City College in 2015, with a second group planned to Brighton in 2016.  Staff development and sharing of best practice in the areas of International mobility, student management and mediation and subject specific knowledge.Course Aims:To provide an opportunity for students to develop hairdressing skills enhancing their employability and career prospects.  To  experience of Norwegian culture and everyday life, to encourage students to learn a new language and raise awareness of the wider European project. To experience similarities and differences in English and Norwegian hairdressing technniques. To improve students personal abilities and self-esteem by living (semi) dependently in a new environment. To gain knowledge and share best practice relating to managing student attendance and mediation techniques.Profile of Participants:Selected will be from  Level 3 Hairdressing course, students aged16-18 year from the Greater Brighton area. Students will have been studying at City College for 18 months having completed a Level 2 Hairdressing qualification the year before. They will have good commercial practical skills for cutting colouring and styling hair.  A maximum of 6 students will participate in this activity. Description of Activities:The mobility course to consist of the following elements (students):Induction welcome and enrolmentTour of Kuben College and its amenitiesGeneral inductionCourse inductionNorwegian CultureAn introduction to Norwegian culture, customs and historyEmployment in NorwayImportance of role and expectationsIce breaker /self introductionOrientation of salonsLearner expectationsCourse expectationsAgreement plan and time table scheduleHealth and safety inductionTheory of Health and Safety Laws required to practice Hairdressing in NorwayPPEIntroduction to Kuben Hairdressing school brand of retail colouring, perming and styling products.Blow drying, setting, styling and creatively dressing long hairColouring – Application of semi-permanent, quasi, permanent , lightening products, bleach , foliing. Fashion techniques for colouringCutting – To extend cutting knowledge for graduating, layering, disconnection. Fashion techniques for cuttingStudents to be given certificates of attendance and course reportsCultural Activities:To include visit to reputable Hair Salons in OsloGuided tour of local main shopping areas and sights of OsloStudents to be advised of best places to to shop, eat out and enjoy nightlifeResults, Impact and longer term benefits:Raised awareness of different cultures amongst both students and staff.Raised awareness of the European project across both institutions.Increase employability of participating students.Empowering students and raising their self-esteem, through exposing them to new culture and experience and through the dissemination activities upon return to CCBH.Developing best practice around limiting student drop-out and mediation.Possibility to build links to offer employment opportunities and work experience.
